title: Put up or shut up on banker pay: APRA
text:
Under the new rules, executives will need to cap the contribution of financial metrics to no more than 50 per cent of bonuses, to include minimum deferral periods of up to seven years and introduce the ability to claw them back for up to four years.

APRA says an over-emphasis on financial metrics has led to poor outcomes for customers, shareholders and institutions and wants boards to consider more than just total shareholder return over a relatively short period.

Proxy advisers, however, say substituting financial measures with non-financial measures is fraught with risk, pointing to the investor backlash against Commonwealth Bank’s executive pay proposal after the bank introduced a “people and community” metric worth 25 per cent.

Better transparency

Investors also found time to savage the design, with one describing the proposal as an “airy-fairy solution” while a former chairman of NAB urged the regulator to reconsider.

Whether they like it or not, APRA’s Mr Byres said executive pay must change and challenged bank boards to come up with a better idea or do their job properly.

“There are two broad ways change can be achieved: more prescription by APRA, or a material change in industry practice, particularly in the use of discretion by boards when considering remuneration outcomes.”

“The most efficient approach would undoubtedly be the latter, but the evidence suggests that will be very difficult, if not impossible, without some form of regulatory backing.”

Advertisement

Mr Byres speech focused on the prudential regulator’s expanding mandate which includes governance, culture, remuneration and accountability (GCRA).

The regulator was forced to admit it was coming up short on this emerging area of interest amongst others including the $2.9 trillion superannuation system following an independent review by Graeme Samuel.

Mr Byers said the regulator planned to be more transparent and as part of that promised to publish more of its findings on the subject of GCRA.

The decision follows an uproar over the number of institutions which opted to keep the results of last year’s GCRA self-assessment a secret.

APRA instructed 36 institutions to complete the process, however, only NAB, Westpac and Australian Super have opted to make the reports public.

My Byres said the regulator was considering forcing companies to make annual GCRA declarations, perform periodic self-assessments and submit to independent CBA-style snap inquiries.

“Our intent is to actively share our findings and insights in relation to GCRA with the industry and the wider public,” Mr Byers said.

“But, at the very least, we foresee routinely making public reports on all thematic reviews and the risk governance self-assessments (including identifying the institutions that are demonstrating better or poorer practice), insights from our risk culture deep dives, and, wherever possible, reports from Prudential Inquiries and similar investigations. “
description: Wayne Byres tells bankers if they don’t like the regulator’s proposals they should have come up with something better.
